text: Is 18k for 2 months for a Italy, Spain, France Portugal holiday enough for everything including flights, accommodation etc… end of July is when I’m planning on going for 2024

comments.comment_text: If you go in off season. May or late Sept a
Are we talking Euros, USD or AUD

I did one month in Rome last year for AUD $4800 airfares and accommodation. This year splitting between Rome and Sicily $5100 including airfare and accommodation. Travelling Sydney to Rome by Emirates

This was my spending for two and a half months, 8 countries. Food was probably lower than most as I’m not a foodie & had a kitchen to cook for myself a lot. Flight Brisbane - Barcelona, Milan - Santorini, Athens- Gold Coast. April-June 2023. I was solo 5 weeks then there were 2 of us for 4 weeks, then 3 of us on the last week.
Anna Guevara Torres
Coming from Australia and spent $20k before leaving home. But that’s flights, accomm, car hire for a couple days, a few trains between cities and really only one group tour.

all depends where from... speaking to a NZ couple last year in Rome where they paid 6k and we paid £200 for flights... I've just booked a month touring round Italy, Pisa, Naples, Sicily and Venice, all flights, cars and hotels for 3k
I live in Italy and these are astronomical numbers for me. I guess the flights are the main reason for such expense.

We live in New Zealand and are in the final week of a four month trip (for 2). I used airpoints to pay for half the flights, by far the most expensive item. Most of our accommodation has been in airbnbs, and we have had a car for almost all the time. We have done quite a bit of eating out, but cooked for ourselves as well. We have spent a little over NZ$30k, so you should be fine.

I def think that’s doable. We are going from aus this year and flying business and it’s prob around the $15k mark. We are doing London 1st for 4nts then over to Italy for approx 5wks. Spending money I can’t tell u what that is yet. But everything is booked including a few food tours etc and some bfasts included.

I learned to travel as a poor student. The lessons learned have allowed me to travel my whole life. In times of little money I would travel with tools and work for housing and food. How much you need is all based on how you travel. I could travel for a year with 18000.
Also if you’re going end of July and into august Italy shuts down in august
Your timing is awful in terms of the temperature and how hot it will be!
Nope. PM me and I’ll give you our costs for our 70 day Italy trip breakdown.

Sounds about right. My 2 week trip to London, Paris and Rome was about 4k for flights/trains/
hotels (Additional expenses of course for food, tours, etc.). I flew from Los Angeles to Heathrow to start
I don't see how it's possible? Unless you're going for extremely cheap accommodations or a hostel. Airfare and hotels alone will eat that budget.
It will be more expensive to go then as it's UK school holidays
I think we're around $3k all in and we're about 4.5 weeks into our Euro trip. Two of us. But I travel on a teachers budget... On a night train from Barcelona to Paris right now 👍
Subtract the airfare because no one knows where you are flying from
We are heading over from Australia 🇦🇺 next week for a month 🙌🏻 we are at about $15500 for 2 adults. That’s flights, accomodation and transfers.
WOW!! That's a lot of $$ to me.
Serina Pippin

You would have to be food shopping and staying apartments not hotels. I could barely make that last 2 weeks let alone 2 months unless I completely changed my eating and activity habits. U can definitely stretch $18k farther than 2 weeks but after travel expenses I think your down to only $15,500 meaning around $258 left per day. If accommodations are $125 per day your left with $133 per day for food and activities. It’s cutting it pretty close , would be more comfortable with $23,000-$25,000
for that period. For what it’s worth we just came back from Croatia, Italy, Ibiza, Mallorca for 19 days and it was $25.5k. Hotels, restaurants for every meal and cabs and activities. We could have cut it down by $5k had we been more frugal on food and accommodations.
We’ve been in Italy and Paris for 7 weeks and for 2 people we’ve spent $24000
Probably not unless it’s for one person. Airfares alone in peak season are expensive.

I just did 5 weeks from Australia, did UK, Netherlands and Italy. I reckon I spent about $12,000. I paid for food and drinks one day and my travelling companion paid for food and drinks the next day so depending on how much eat and drink you might squeeze it in. What $ are you converting from?
If you be if you stay in pensiones and eat inexpensively. We spent more than that on four people for three weeks in Italy, Switzerland and France.
We just spent 50K for 2 months
Anyone on a really tight budget could look at House/pet sitting holidays - free accommodation in exchange for pet care

So I keep seeing posts like this. People are using the a TA that prepares a “package”. For these prices (I am up in your number) I am hand picking everything. No way I would just book some unknown package of stuff with no invoicing for everything.

Yes
Keep your accommodations cheap that was one of the biggest expenses besides the flight .
Sounds good.. I spent $9k in 2019 from Texas to Egypt and Greece for 12 days. 9 days in Egypt and 3 days in Athens..
There are a lot of variables but the simple answer is yes.
Depends on where your flying from. I just came back from Italy 3 weeks a family of 4 and it was well over 20,000

Errr depends . I usually allow 5k for two weeks ( and I stay free with relatives) . I think you are cutting it close. Please buy health insurance for traveling. Yes it is a waste of money . ( a twisted ankle on cobblestones will change tour mind). Remember the people who live there are used to the cobblestones in the mediaeval villages are used to them -u are not.
No
You start with a budget and find flights, transportation and accommodations to fit. That is how I plan. $18k for two months sounds like a comfortable budget to me. I could totally make that work!

I could put it together myself for way less than that.
Buy a ticket into one city and out another. Use Rome2Rio to book everything in between.

Your biggest expense will be lodging. As a couple, we budget $100/day for lodging, which is usually apartments, most of which include a washer. That would be $6,000. Rental or leased car $2,500/month or $5,000. Food, gas, tickets and miscellaneous, we usually average $100/day our $6,000, but we don't eat out every meal and do some cooking at home. (With all the beautiful produce in the many markets, it is difficult to pass that up). Airfare from US, depending on time of year is usually $1,000 pp or $2,000. So, for us, $19,000 would cover it. Add in travel insurance and maybe some type of health care, and your $20k makes sense. This allows a wonderful trip in clean, well-located apartments and mostly casual dining. You can spend more, or even tighten the belt a bit more.
We spent double that for our two month trip! But included spending $$ as well!
Natalia Litwinczuk ❤️
My trip is costing 20k for 5 weeks. This includes all flights, accomodation, transport and spending money. I am also from Aus.
$30k aud for 1 month for 3 of us. Hoping it doesn’t go over leave in 1 week.

July is extremely hot in Italy and Spain. Not sure about France. April/May and September/
October are perfect. Less crowds. Not hot. Lines aren’t as long.
The best and very economical is tripmasters and Greatvalue. We’ve used them twice in Ireland, 4x Italy, Greece and Spain. You can chose premium economy very minimal added to the whole tour
Flights can be over 2000 return alone

For our family I usually estimate the following average breakdown when we travel to Italy. This number is estimated & we stay in Italy.. so it does not include travel betwen counties. Per person: NJ to Italy
1-Flight- $1000- 1200 average east coast to Italia ) we go summer so more $! Direct too
2-Accommodation
s - $100-125 night per person. We only do hotels and apartment/hotel
3- Food / drink - we usually eat sit down casual dinner rest food on go - $75-90 day
4- misselabeous ( transportation/
tickets) -total 200-300$ 2 week stay
That = 11,500- 12,000on low end - if u cook all ur meals and stay in maybe lower….
That’s just my math… anyway hope that helps. Again u can save on food n board if you spend less and maybe Air BB- we like hotels though. Good luck 🍀
I hope so. Depends on you
Very doable.
I reckon about 30,000 for a family of 4 from Australia
We spend about that much for two months and that includes business air from the US. We do not stay at high end hotels so if you do, then I would think you will need more.
There are cruises from Italy to France and than to Barcelona. That way you can save some money and enjoy the ship. Check MSC cruises🙂
I just got back from 3 weeks in Europe 2 if which were in Italy…. Way too hot 🥵 to enjoy it to the fullest. I don’t recommend July

My flight from Perth to Rome $2300 , paid for my window seat x 4 , insurance with my credit card + have been going for 16 years and would never go in peak season so hot , why not September or even October good months 🌻

My husband and I were in Italy from the U.S. in March and part of April for 16 days. Booked into a tour for 11 days and 5 on our own. We booked 5 months in advance. Venice, Pisa, Florence, Cinque Terre, Assisi, Rome, Pompeii, Sorrento and spent approximately $12,000 total! It was the week of Easter in part. Beautiful weather! Have fun!

We’re doing 5 weeks for 18.5k
Uk/ England from aus
To Sicily, then flight to Naples and hormone a camper can for 2 weeks before flying Milan home

We’re not seeing much or doing any tours in Sicily

I’d say it’s doable

We just came back from 2 weeks in Italy and Greece and spent over 10k each. Flights are your biggest expense, We are also from Australia and spent $4k each on flights and we bought almost a year in advance!! Accommodation is your next biggest expense, its tricky to say as different regions have very different prices, we tried to balance with spending more on accommodation in some and less in others. Just do your research and know what your priorities are!
Not enough, for 2 people from Australia. Probs $10k more

Another thing to consider - it may not help now but in the future - when I went to italy, I booked hotels/plane tickets using my credit card points I would have accumulated and AAdvantage points. This helps alot. My trip cost was cut in half!

Albeit I only went for 2 weeks - but I saw that the hotels were significantly cheaper when booking it through the AAdvantage Rocket Hotel listings on their website.

So if you don't have one already, consider a credit card that accumulates points towards travel. Just be super disciplined with the way you use it - I use mine for EVERY transaction, even for a stick of gum in the supermarket :)

Imo there is no way we can answer that question. I'm assuming 2 people? Do you want to stay in AirBnB's or 5 star hotels? City trips or country-side? Maybe get a rough idea of what you would like and consult with a travel agent to get an idea of pricing?

I’m staying in Italy 59 days in 2024 and I’m figuring $12,OOO for flights, accommodations,
food, tickets, trains- one person me. I’m not going to spend big $ on restaurants- I’m staying at Airbnb moderate stays- and will travel by train and use Rick Steve’s audio guides for tours at major sites.
Currency, types of stay, eating habits, the list goes on……….

I feel like you can do this economically and intelligently! You need a travel agent and some research. There has to be some point if you are spending this much you are looking for everything to be high end or you are just setting money on fire. I’m not sure which. I’d love to know how this is adding out this way? Are you booking private transportation and staying the whole trip in hotels? I think you can make it Nice and be intelligent about it.

text: Ciao! Do you know any beautiful places in Calabria?

Planning trip for next July. Only time i can go. Planing for Venice Florence Rome Amalfi. First and main question is flights. Leaving from nyc. I had planned flying into Venice. Head south via trains. Then fly out of Naples. But these flights are crazy expensive. Most reasonable seem in/out of Rome but not sure. Any suggestions/experiences?

comments.comment_text: We are here now. Flew from JFK direct to Venice. Doing the same going back.
Rome has more international flights in & out- Milan is the other. Best purchases are from these two because of volume of flights.
If you can only go in July, don’t go. I’m just being honest. It it just too dangerously hot and very humid. Wait until you can go in a cooler month even if for a shorter time.

But how much extra will it cost in money and time to back track and catch extra time. Go in a line either north or south. I would fly into Naples and go straight to Amalfi on first day. Then head north and fly out of Venice. That’s minimum 14 days.
Recommend visiting as early in June as possible or a different season than Summer. Sweltering heat, insane crowds and pricing.

Hi, try flying out of Newark into venice, then Florence, amalfi/naples via train, end your trip in Rome… fly from Fiumicino back to Newark, since you are in NYC, if that works. We booked tickets first week of January and got a great fare.
We are doing Rome (round trip) because it’s nonstop both ways and good price. Upon arrival in Rome going first to Amalfi, then Florence, Venice, Cinque Terre and ending in Rome.

When I flew to Venice last year I had to connect in Heathrow omg what a pain getting from gate to gate especially after my flight was delayed leaving JFK. But I do love Marco Polo Airport on Venice. And not going to lie, I loved taking a private water taxi from airport to the hotel. It was pricy but omg lovely after the long flights and rush to gate and such.
We flew out of jfk on emirates into Milan it was the cheapest
Price the train tickets for one way and then the other. You might find it comes out about even
Rome is more reasonable in flights. That’s where we are landing.
Go to some of the less crowded places in Italy .... So much nicer and less expensive. Head south by train in a couple of stops to somewhere like Bari and then fly back up to catch your NYC flight.
What airline? United has daily flights out of Newark to Milan and Rome. It might be worth checking into if you haven’t already.
Delta JFK to Venice direct and then trains in between and fly from Naples through Paris back to JFK.
We bought a package for Rome through Expedia and airlines and hotel were cheaper. Than just purchasing airline tickets. I think it’s too early to book. Wait at least six months before your date
We’re flying into Rome and out of Venice .
Multi city flights are off the charts, we have the same dilemma so will probably fly in and out of one city if nothing changes.

text: Hi all! We will have the opportunity to go from Switzerland to Italy August 17-20. I was thinking of flying into Rome as a home base. I am concerned a out the temperatures, places closing etc so wondering if maybe staying closer to the coast is probably better and doing a day trip to Rome? We've never been and I would absolutely love to go but hopefully it isn't the worst idea ever? I'm ok with 85* but 90-100* in crowded areas seems terrible. I'm open to staying wherever in Italy to be honest. Suggestions? Thank you soooo much!!

For anyone that is travelling from Bari to Rome via train I would consider flying rather than taking the train. Obviously more expensive to fly, but in this heat the train was way too hot. We had first class tickets but the air conditioning was only in the one section of the train that sold food/drinks. 2 hours into the 4 hour ride they had sold out of all cold drinks and ran out of ice cubes. Not an enjoyable train ride!

text: Would like to plan a trip to Italy next summer June/ July. Sorrento,capri, Amalfi coast. Book with a tour or do it on my own?suggestions? Thank you 😊

comments.comment_text: Do it on your own much easier forget hotels get an apartment its spacious much more comfortable we always do self catering now
On your own, get a private driver, book this airbnb 4711 Boutique Apartment and they will offer help with planning and it'll all be amazing.
Been there do your own settle in Sorrento then take day trips . Ferry over to Capri for the day. Take a boat tour to positano and or Ravello etc

We took a small tour (10people on the boat) to the Blue Grotto to see the cave and then to Capri for a few hours to explore on our own. It picked us back up and took us back to Sorrento pointing out some landmarks and other grottos. Lastly they stopped so people could swim. It was very nice.

I just went last month. I was nervous to book it on my own and so glad I did. We were able to go at our pace and see what we wanted to see. I knew what cities I wanted to go on and booked a couple of day tours. The longest one was 3 hours. Once you get started you won’t be overwhelmed

text:
Just got back from Italy a few weeks ago and this was one of the lovely beaches in Sirolo I had the pleasure of visiting! I am ready to plan my trip for next year! Can this wonderful group help?
I want toआणखी visit Sardinia this time and as a family of 4 looking for ( my kids are older 22 and 16 so does not need to be little kid friendly)
1- great recommendations for hotel or airbnbs.
2-not to be missed beaches and natural sites
3- best towns for exploring and siteseeing
4- where to get the best food
5- anything off the beaten path that can be fun.
Thanks friends!

comments.comment_text:
I am Sardinian, so I think I can help you 🫠
1. In Cagliari I can recommend you "Sa fabbrica de Sant'Anna", a lovely b&b, but if you want I can ask more specifically and in other cities
2. Beaches from south to north (my favourites) Solanas, Villasimius, Chia, Tuerredda, Cala Cipolla, Piscinas, Mari Ermi, Cala Cartoe, Cala Luna, Cala Gonone, La Maddalena, Alghero.
3. Cagliari and Sassari are very tourist friendly, and with a car and google maps you can move all around the isle. Don't stick to the coast and try visiting also the center: it is incredible and very genuine (and food is AMAZING).
5: google "canyon di Gorroppu" and "villaggio nuragico di Barumini".
(also, I live in Marche and I teach specifically in the middle school of Sirolo :) hope you've had a great time here!)
Amazing

text: Hi, Going to Italy in September. I have a concern....I frequently need to use a restroom as I have a bladder condition. Are there places they let you use? Or do I have to actually be at a restaurant or café to use the restroom? A bit worried, silly I know!

comments.comment_text: Not a silly question at all!🥰
Thanks everyone, it's very re-assuring! I will carry coins and TP with me.
You do have to pay for some toilets, but find mc Donald's, kfc, etc. Walk into hotel lobby's like your staying there as there are always toilets on ground floor. Good luck.
Carry one euro coins
Me too!!
We had no trouble at all during the month we just spent in Italy. Only paid twice, and that was at railway stations. My motto is always use one when you see one, whether you need it or not.

At some train stations you need to pay to use the tickets, so try to have some €1 coins handy! Other stations, especially more rural, have what I like to call ‘medieval toilets’ (you basically have to stand/squat and pee into a hole in the ground🤣). Otherwise if you’re out and about, I’m sure there are plenty of cafes/bars that will be happy to let you use the toilet! The italian phrase would be ‘posso usare il bango’ (bango pronounced like ‘ban-yo’) - I’m sure the staff would appreciate your effort at using italian!🫶🏽
Get the Flush app, it shows where the public toilets are, very handy to have.
Download the Flush App. You can find public toilets anywhere in the world.
Buy yourself some leak proof undies eg- period pants. This helps in urgent situations

Flush is a great global toilet finder app!
Restaurants for the most have good toilets for paying customers to use , always use them before you leave !
You need to purchase something and I’ve haven’t had one bathroom without TP.
Bring toilet paper with you and euros!

Danielle Genest Godfrey, it’s not silly!! Many of us need to know if needed that there are accessible toilets nearby. It’s a fair question!! I’m thinking of going September, October next year. Enjoy your trip. 🤗🇦🇺
We had no problems. Don’t worry. Sometimes you may need a tissue, but fall less then in America!
Add 2 euros per time you use the bathroom to your budget. You can plan to buy something to eat each time you need to use the bathroom.
Bring coins (euro), so you can use the public restrooms, they are around. We even walked right in to 2 different McDonald’s in Rome- one was a 50 coin and the other free.

Just choose a restaurant that has outdoor seating walk into the back of it (bathrooms are in the back or downstairs) if u can’t see them ask waiter Bagno??? They have no idea if your a customer or not….. I did it countless times, good luck and don’t worry!

I purchased toilet seat covers from Amazon. I carried a small pack of travel tissues, and individual antibacterial wipes. All three of these fit into a very small and very nice zipper pouch. You can also add a few 1 Euro coins to the pouch. If you buy a pack of gum, or a cup of coffee in Italy you can use the bathroom in the restaurants for free.. Even many museums have a one euro charge to use the bathroom. I think it was Spain that you could walk right into any bar or restaurant and simply use the bathroom. Different cultures- different rules. But definitely consider bringing the toilet seat covers, personalized pack of tissues, and antibacterial wipes. Lots of toilets do not have seats
I have the same problem. We just stop for a water or coke if I need a restroom and there are not public restrooms available. Trains and train stations also have restrooms. Nothing to worry about.
Well,,,, that depends…
Yes except to buy lots of coffee or cold drinks or pastries in cafes.
In Venice no problem finding a public restroom but you have to pay one euro! In Florence and Rome we begged our bladders to do its business before we left restaurants! 😬

I am so glad you asked this question! I am stressing about this as my tummy can get upset. In Portugal last year the trains we took did not appear to have a bathroom…my nightmare to be trapped on a moving vehicle for an hour or two without. I am downloading the flush app and creating my itinerary for September around it 😂. We will be there 9/24… we will both be looking for facilities!
Download the flush app. It shows you where public bathrooms are worldwide
Blimey half the people on here should be called 'Karen'

What about strolling on ,and asking quickly ,may i go to the bathroom, its urgent
Thank you
It's not silly if it's a medical requirement. Please don't feel it is. I would recommend taking some tissue with you though xx
Wear a diaper lol 😂 🤦🏻‍♀️
I saw a tip online to use library bathrooms

We are in Italy now and have not had any issues with finding washroom to use. Walk into any medium to large size restaurant and use the facilities. The small places may not have a toilet for the customers.

My husband had the same issue. We bought lots of bottled water just to accommodate. We found it to be problematic. Also during the afternoon lots of restaurants were not open. Small cafes that served Cappuccino were his best options.
Take a couple of small toilet paper 'ends', in ziplocks, and keep one on your purse.

It’s nothing silly about it at all! I search restrooms quite often as a matter of fact. A great excuse to get un caffè or aqua for €1 or €2 at a bar, and go straight to the restroom. Bring some tissues and be prepared to squat! I carry a small roll of TP in my bag. Some restaurants actually have an attending maid charging for 50 cents for the service, by the way.
Here now and I use the bathroom a lot. No issue-just buy a water or drink or snack and use it! And carry one euro coins in case.
There is a really useful app you can download called Flush
Have to pay for toilet in some places
I drank a lot of decaf espresso lol. One to 2 euros for the espresso, and I could use their bathroom when I needed. ￼
Pack tissues/toilet paper with you and buy a bottled water or snack if you go into a cafe. We didn’t have many issues with finding places.

text:
This page has been so helpful for me and so I want to pay it forward. For those of you wanting to go to the Pantheon in Rome. Get your tickets BEFORE you go. It will save you a lot of time and stress with the heat and system not working properly. Trust me. First day we went and could not get the app to work, the line for tickets was really long and it was HOT so we gave up. I was able to get them from my computer and go back without any line.
Use the link below to get to the site: Create your login > Choose your tickets > Go to your cart to checkout > It will take you to another site where you input your email address > Then you must choose your payment option. * I was able to ONLY get Paypal to work through Intesa Sanpaolo S.p.A. option. Click on "other payment options" to get to that. That was the ONLY way that would work for me. I am SO glad I do not have to wait in that long line today in this 100 degree heat.
Here is the link: https://portale.museiitaliani.it/

(You may have to click another link on this page to get there but it’s possible)

Another tip: Rick Steves free tour is perfect for the Pantheon! Save your money for more gelato! ❤️

text: Trying to arrange a day trip from Rome to Pompeii. I was looking at getting the train and then a tour guide at the site, but have seen coach trips are an option too. When I look at booking trains they all seem to be very different times, prices and often the final station isn’t Pompeii Scavi. Anyone offer any advice or help?! I was looking at going Sunday 13th Aug but could go on the 12th if travelling Sundays is more difficult. Thank you 😊

comments.comment_text:
Go to website seat61 and there are directions on how to get there. You will take the high speed train to Naples and then get on the regional train to Pompeii Scavi stop. I think in the summer there is a train that goes from Naples to Sorrento with a stop at Pompeii. We were there in February and took the regional train. The tourist train wasn’t running then. It is a pretty slow train but it totally worked. It will be super hot on the regional train and probably crowded. There is no air conditioning. You could also hire a driver to pick you up at the train station and take you to Pompeii. You can also do a tour that will handle the transportation.
I personally would not take a bus from Rome to Pompeii. That will waste a bunch of time. Maybe there is a tour that picks up at the train station. Good luck!

First of all, you need to take a high speed train called Frecciarossa or Italo from Roma Termini to Napoli Centrale. Then go underground path to Piazza Garibaldi/
Circumvesuviana station. Purchase ticket to Pompeii Scavi(buy round trip tix at the window). Only Circumvesuviana
SORRENTO LINE stops at Pompeii Scavi.

For high speed trains, download Trenitalia app or Italo app.
Every time I took a train I just searched "high speed train city "x" to city "y" and it would come right up

comments.comment_text: Second hand stores can be found in every town, but then people can give clothes in good condition to several associations or to their neighbourhood church.

If instead you are interested in buying used clothes, there are places where you can buy them, depending on the city.

There are second hand shops in Rome esp. Monti area.
In Google maps enter Thrift Store. That said, France was better…….
Only through churches I found, they have vintage shops but nothing like Australia has charity shops 🌻

text: We are thinking about spending our 30th anniversary is Italy in May 2024. We’ve been before and did all the big stuff. We want 7-10 days of just relaxing, maybe some beach time and maybe a day trip or two. Trying to stay away from overly crowded areas. I just want to eat and drink lots of coffee! 😂Any suggestions ?

comments.comment_text: Spend half in a small town in Tuscany, and the rest on the coast. We were just there for 16 days and we spent 4 of them near a small town called Reggelo, about 30 min from Florence. It was quiet and we had a rental car to cruise around during the days exploring and doing wine tastings. Absolutely loved it. Another option Lucca, it was a little busier but still one of the quietest spots on our trip we loved it.
Look into Ischia (island in bay of Naples) for beach and local feel. Great resorts and vibe at a fraction of Amalfi Coast. Know for its thermal waters and hot springs.
We have just booked Tropea for September Chill week.

May can be very hot, but it can also be very rainy. If you want to be sure to find a perfect weather to relax and have some sea time, you should go to Sicily. Sicily has both some of the most beautiful beaches of Italy and wonderful cities to visit.

text:
Hi everyone travelling to Italy in 2 weeks.
Staying in Rome 3 days Naples and Positano 4 days Florence 3 days everything is booked. However have decided to extend and go to Cinque Terre for 4 days and won’t have a car just trains. I love to be by the water/beach and would love some suggestions of what part of Cinque Terre would be the best and most convenient without costing a fortune!!
Thanks in advance

comments.comment_text: Riomaggiore. We are here now. There is a beach jist past where you would board the ferry. Very easy to get to, just walk along the stone path. You can buy towels for $5 if you don’t have any. Towels to buy would be up along main road in town.

Hands down: Vernazza! The most charming. Been twice. Bawled when I left. It’s the town the Disney movie “Luca” is fashioned after.

If you enjoy hiking, split the gorgeous scenic hike into 2 jaunts. South to North. Train to Rio and hike to Vernazza. Another day, hike Vernazza to Monterosso.

Another great day trip from CT is taking the public boat to Portovenere. Stunning.

Highly recommend staying at La Mala in Vernazza. Fab stone terrace with amazing sea views. It’s at the top of cliff, so there are stairs. But it’s soooo worth it!

CT known for its amazing pesto and focaccia.

As far as convenience, all villages are easy, up to what you’re looking for and lodging you find. I feel Vernazza is best layout. Small so it’s not a trek to get to lodging.

4 days is a perfect amount of time. You can savor and enjoy without spreading yourself thin.

Buon viaggio!

If you want a good beach, Monterosso al Mare is the one to choose. Having said that, it is not really typical of the other villages in that it is on fairly level terrain. The others are on steep hills. You can take the train or boat to all the nearby destinations.
I am not sure if you’ll be able to find accommodation if you have not already booked it.

Monterosso was great and right on beach. But honestly you could stay at any. So easy to hike to each and hop on train so easily in each village. It takes 10mins to get from Monterosso to farthest village.
Monterosso or La Spezia
We were recommended by a travel agent who specializes in Italy to stay in Portovenere so that is where we will be staying in October.
Vernazza, excellent and great swimming everything is so close and excellent restaurant s

Monterosso is right at the start and a great place to stay. We caught the train to visit all the other towns, plus you can walk between them.
Just beautiful! Enjoy your trip.
Thanks for all the feedback really appreciated x

comments.comment_text: For Garda lake, consider Sirmione or Peschiera and plan daytrip to Verona, as well as the lake west coast
Bardolino would be a good base in Lake Garda. Lots of restaurants, Garda is easy to walk or cycle to, and you could get ferries to Sirmione or other towns

We stayed pitti palace side of Florence a much more chilled side , more trendy bars and relaxed restaurants , the other side is crazy busy
We stayed near arsenale in Venice again , much more reasonable and lovely local restaurants
Firenze stay in Oltrarno less touristy and less busy but still central or maybe around Santa Croce.
Venice stay in Santa Croce, San Polo or Canareggio.

Florence: Casa G (stylish boutique in heart of Florence)

Lake Garda: Prati Prati. A bit of Tuscan modern feel. Pool. Lovely. We enjoyed renting bikes and riding along the river to fairytale villages.
On Lake Garda we stayed in Nago-Torbole at the Hotel Lago di Garda -- we had a beautiful room with a large deck and private hot tub. The views were jaw dropping gorgeous. Highly recommended
We are staying in San polo on Venice at the moment it’s a really nice area

Just depends on your itinerary and sightseeing ventures. For example in Florence we stayed close to the duomo (about 1/2 mile away) and this was close enough to everything like accedemia, uffizi, Arno etc
In Florence, stayed at the Hotel Duomo Firenze. I had a room with a view. 😊

Lake Garda is stunning. We loved staying in Malcesine which is devine and from there a trip on the cable car up to mt Baldo and visit across the lake at Limone and up to the head of the Lake to Riva del Garda. Then we caught the fast ferry with our luggage down the lake to Sirmione which is gorgeous and stayed at hotel Eden right next to ferry stop. It’s a beautiful village within a moated town complete with medieval castle you can visit. We visited Verona on the local bus from here also. The closest train stn is Peschiera del Garda. Hope this helps.
Malcesine or Limone in Garda. Avoid Riva and Serimone.

text: My partner uses a c pap to sleep. Is it difficult to find distilled water??

comments.comment_text: You can find it at most grocery stores. It’s in the section with the laundry detergent.
You can’t use regular bottled water. The SmartWater brand bottled water is however, distilled and relatively easy to find.
Oftentimes found in the automotive section.
Your partner might find that short term they can forego the water. That is what my husband did in Egypt. There was no distilled water to be found tin that country except in tiny tubes
I read on a different thread that you can get it at a pharmacy but have to ask as they keep it behind the counter.
Janice
My husband also didn’t use water for his cpap in Italy. It worked fine.

The only place my husband was able to find distilled water was at la Farmacia. He paid 3 euros for a one litre bottle. We searched many grocery stores both in Rome and Pescara and we did not find seeing that they do not sell it.

We were told by our cpap provider that we could use bottled water during that time which we did w/o any issues for my husband’s machine or any less effectiveness. We were able to find distilled water in one place. Just be sure you don’t buy water with gas (carbonated) which is very popular there.
It can be in Europe, you may have to go to multiple places and in pharmacies it’s usually behind the counter so ask them
And what about plugging the CPAP machine into wall with converter-any problems?

I have been using my cpap machine for 5 years and use tap water. I clean the basin with a vinegar, dawn dish soap and water solution when lime starts to show. I have never had any machine issues and my AHI numbers are exactly where they should be.
As my grandfather used to say “Eh! Whatsa the differn’?” 😊
My Cpap you can turn the humidifier off if you don’t have distilled water.
You can find in pharmacies. Need to ask pharmacist, as they keep it behind the counter.

Hubs is new to cpap ... I refuse to spend my vaca in a grocery store so we will take it from home in our stainless water bottle and then transfer to a cheap plastic bottle (from water we buy at a coffee shop etc) #teamcheckedlugg
age but how do we plug it in ?
My doctor said tap water is fine.
You don't have to put water in it. I never use water in mine, even at home
I haven’t used distilled water in over 30 years and mine works just fine
Walmart

You need to buy in it in the pharmacy “Farmacia” ask the pharmacist for Aqua depurata

I know it costs more, but I bought an Air Mini before my trip to Iceland back in July of last year. It does not require a reservoir with water. It is my travel CPAP so I don’t have to worry about the distilled water.
Best to boil the water first and let it cool down before adding to the machine

Consider buying a travel cpap device. Requires no water and is smaller than a kindle and about 2 inches tall
If you travel a lot it is worth it!
Every Pharmacy had it. Just had to ask
I bought a mini CPAP that requires no water…it’s very small and light.

any supermarket… or worst case boil some water

text:
Help! We are going to Rome in August for 3 nights = 2 full days. The more I research on Rome, the more I realize I could spend 2 months there and still not see it all! So my question is: If you had only 2 days in Rome, what would your top 5 sights/areas to explore be?
I want to lower my expectations of how much is realistic to see in 2 days. I am… आणखी going to book the Colosseum night tour direct through coopculture and I've already booked a 2hr Guruwalk tour for one of our mornings.
My husband and I are open to walking and exploring all day long, but so far I'm thinking:
Colosseum, Roman Forum, and Palatine Hill (late afternoon into evening)
Trevi Fountain and Spanish Steps (early morning)
2 hr Guruwalk tour (morning; starts at Piazza Venezia and ends at Campo de Fiori)
Explore Trastevere (where we are staying)
Baths of Caracalla


(P.S. Not too interested in going into the Vatican/St. Peters)
Helpful input appreciated please :)

comments.comment_text: Castel Sant’ Angelo is my favorite

Rome is pretty easy to walk around. The colosseum is good and takes a couple of hours. You don’t need to spend too much time at the Spanish steps and Trevi fountain. Take in the piazza’s and enjoy a drink and people watching We did the hop on hop off bus tour which was a good way to see everyone and work out where everything was. We Went up to the Vatican but didn’t go in.

Be sure to taste pizza and gelato from the tiny shops everywhere.
Seek restaurants where there are lots of people - a great ad!
At Camp di Fiori - linger for lunch after you ogle all the fabulous fish and flowers and sugared orange rind.
From the Campo, walk to Piazza Navona - just a few blocks and it’s SPLENDID.
You could spend 2 YEARS and not see Rome!
I’d skip the Baths of Caracalla; go sit in the middle of the Piazza fella Rotondo and be awed with the Pantheon. Walk inside and look up.
Get coffee and/or gelato here, too ( in fact get them EVERYwhere😀)
Shelby Britton some great tips for Rome!
Hop On Hop Off bus. Coliseum and Vatican

Posters here are right - the Vatican IS a must. But not on a hot day when it’s so crowded you can’t even linger.
Skip it for when you have a decent amount of time to devote to it properly.
I would do willa Borghese gardens instead of Bath of Caracalla
Do the hop on hop off bus tour which will give you a good overview of the city and you can get off and on at the different stops

A few "alternative" ways: Colosseum night tour is amazing. Trevi and Spanish Steps not so busy v late night or v early morn. Breakfast in Vatican 7.30 am I think, has been highly recommended here. If you're into running, there are early morning running tours around Rome, I haven't done it but it is highly recommended. Also, the church of San Clemente is absolutely FAB! Hidden gem! It's an easy one to do in the afternoon, cool cos inside, has amazing ruins on 3 floors below. https://
basilicasancleme
nte.com/eng/

Trust me. Go to the vadican City (preferably with a guide to get more out of it) and pay an extra €8 to go up the top of the dome. There are 3 sections you get access to. I spent about a week in Rome and going up that dome was my favourite thing by far.

We enjoyed the Villa Borghese gardens as a nice reprieve from the city noise, pollution, and crowds. And right across the bridge from Trastevere is the Jewish Ghetto. There are so many old ruins there with interesting history and no one around. I found the art installation with gold cobblestones that listed the names, birthdates, date of deportation, name of the camp, and date of death in front of different doorways (where these people used to live) particularly moving.

We are only there that amount of time as well
So doing the golf cart tour to at least see all of the landmarks and just doing St. Peter’s Basilica and not the Vatican and Sistine except from the outside. Also doing Borghese Gardens and a food tour in Trastevere 🙂

Borghese Galleria is amazing, and is set in a lovely park, near the Spanish Steps. The Spanish Steps are underwhelming and take about a minute. If you are at all interested in incredible art, I highly recommend the Borghese Galleria. Book in advance, takes 2 hours maximum (timed entry).

Take the hop on hop off buss and do the whole tour. Decide where you want to go on the 2th round after seeing all the highlights from the buss and in the evening just wander in the streets round the famous squares and enjoy ! If you throw a coin in the Trevi fountain (over your shoulder) you will be back in the eternal city 🇮🇹

Although you've said no to Vatican, I would do the st Peters basilica and travel up to the cupula to see the view from the top. We did Vatican museum and although it had nice things in, it wasn't the best thing for such a short trip. I'd also say St Agnatsia perspective ceiling. Spelt it wrong but a quick Google will tell you all about it. Nothing to look at outside but fab inside. A quick visit on route to colluseum would allow you to fit it in. Enjoy your trip.
One major place each day then enjoy a long lunch, Apertivo and late dinner! In between stop for espresso. After the 15th many local restaurants close for 2 weeks
Do a night tour of the colosseum. It's incredible at night, and you'll beat the heat.

We loved going to the top of St Peter's Basilica dome (we used a Tiquets tour which was great). Personally I was not overwhelmed by The Vatican. Loved the map corridor and some of the mosaic floors. Good to tick off and our evening tour had lovely light on the buildings. Everyone's opinion is different of course!
Take a golf cart tour. See an overview. Great. Then go back and see sights.

I would skip the Vatican. It's over the top ostentatious, and quite frankly pisses me off that a religious order would have that kind of money. AND charge me an arm and a leg to see it. AND have a dress code. There are so many other wonderful things to see, do and eat. I've been all over Italy many times over and Rome is at the top of my list for large cities, history, and the best food in the country. The most memorable ruins are the Colosseum and Nero's Palace. Both are otherworldly and incredibly memorable (esp Nero)

If you don't enter in museums, you can do a lot':
1 day-- Colosseo +circo massimo + piazza Venezia ed altare della patria + piazza Navona+trevi+ campo de fiori + piazza di spagna + piazza popolo e Pincio
2 day --- castel sant angelo , bocca della verità , san Pietro (Just piazza),Trastev
ere , Gianicolo

You Need to walk alot but with no entrance you can do It!

I THINK Spanish steps and trevi are in opposite directions? Not sure. Do trevi first thing and skip the big crowsa. We went at 7am and it was pretty good. We then walked to St peters and got there early too and was a very short quick line. You're mad to miss it!

Item 2: if you want to do with no one in the photo (Trevii Fountain & Spanish Steps), I would go around 5AM. By 6, there was a good amount of people there (from when I did both 5&6AM) less than a week ago.
Coliseum, tour of the Vatican
We did the Catacombs and Crypts underground tour, it was really different and interesting. Good to do on a hot day!
Get a scooter and do all that during the night , it was an awesome experience ❤️
Take a golf cart tour or the hop on hop off bus

If you have any time at all the Basilica in Rome is amazing. Doesn’t take the time the Vatican does. The art in it is breathtaking. One of my favorite experiences is climbing to the top and seeing the view of Rome. Besides the coliseum, it’s not to be missed. Rick Steves has an amazing free audio tour of the Vatican. He made it come alive and I learned so much.
My best recommendation is to stay at least a week
Add Pantheon

You could spend years in Rome and still not see it all.. Your plan seems a good one though. I would consider the Pantheon, the Aventino where the Giardino degli Aranci is, and the Gianicolo, a walk from trastevere
We had private tour with local and she walked us all the spots over 8 hr period and she provided the hx it was great if you have little time.
The Vatican is a must
Vatican is worth it, the art is phenomenal and it’s really not about a secular churchy kind of thing. More pertaining to history and art. Go with a guided group first thing in the morning
I would hire a good tour guide for all of the 1st day and then you have the sights seen. And spend the 2nd day, relaxing and strolling around yourselves.

Trastevere is great - best place to spend majority of the time we literally sped past trevi fountain and spanish steps - loads of litter and tourists. I'd happily not go back to central Rome now I've walked past it all. Trastevere i'd happily return to many times, really nice vibe around there. Albeit, I do always prefer neighbourhoods to the true city centres. Vatican is 95% an art gallery, with no time to actually stop and look as you're sheparded through each room, I'd expected the guided tour to focus more on the religion side of things but its all about the art, which personally i'm not into.

Do you plan on never returning?
Famous travel expert Rick Steves says "Travel like you'll be back again".
On that short a trip and in August, I'd do what the weather permits. It's going to be hot. You don't want to be standing in lines eating up precious time. Eat, drink and be merry! Wander around and take gelato breaks and/or spritz breaks whenever you are so moved. Just walking you can see the history in the architecture etc. Remove the Vatican from the equation and there's still tons to see.
Don't miss Vatican , it's spectacular. If you still find slots, do the early morning visit with breakfast.

Vatican/
Sistine Chapel, Coliseum, Spanish Steps, Castel Sant'Angelo, Pantheon, Trevi Fountain, Piazza Navona, Galleria Borghese/Villa Borghese,. Trastevere.
Pizza Navona one night is a must. Its hot out there so museums, galleries and cafes!!

Same here. 2-1/2 days in Rome. Thr first day I figure jet lag so I scheduled a late afternoon golf cart tour. Next day is all day walking tour and exploring. I'm skipping Vatican too. Would love to see it, but will have to be next time!

Trevi and Spanish steps are a few minutes to see and take pics. We did them each night after dinner. Colosseum and Forum book a tour. We had a 3 hr tour it was more than thorough (I could have done in less time). We did a golf cart tour in 3 hours can take your everywhere!

text:
Am missing my beloved Italia already 😪
We returned home to Australia on Saturday from 4 weeks away, taking in Paris and Zurich before hitting Italy 🥰
First stop (by train) was Bellagio. It was insanity at Como when we arrived, huge queue for ferry tickets and fast ferries sold out hours in advance. Looked at the bus option, which was even worse that day 🙈 so got a slow ferry a few hours later and enjoyed a leisurely lunch while we waited. Got to Bellagio and were beyond happy. It’s been 16yrs since our last visit! Not much has changed, and we frequented our favourite bar by the water every afternoon. A day trip to Menaggio and Varenna (gorgeous lunch stop). A day trip to FoxTown on the Swiss border - we have previously driven from Switzerland into Italy and we love a shopping stop there, bargains to be had! - so we caught the train up. Took the bus to/from Como that day, the views were superb, and it only takes slightly longer than a fast ferry (for about 1/4 of the price). Our 4nts flew.
Second stop Venice, which we haven’t seen for 10yrs. I wasn’t sure how much we would enjoy it, but I can safely say we loved it! Our daughter was four last time we went, so clearly this made a huge difference. We did a gondola for the first time. We had cocktails (a mocktail for the 14yo!) at a rooftop bar, we caught Vaporetto everywhere, found some great cafes, we checked out the views from the DFS roof - link in comments, book 21 days in advance, it’s free and a must-do - and we had a great apartment on the Grand Canal. Loved every second of our three night stay.
We collected a car from Europcar and drove down as far as San Benedetto del Tronto for an over nighter to break up the journey to Monopoli. Arrived in magnificent Monopoli the following afternoon and WOW. Just WOW! It was like entering a travel brochure! We had rented an apartment in the old town, which you’re able to drive into btwn 3:30-5:30 for only 15 mins to unload your bags and then get out, as it’s a pedestrian-only area. I cannot recommend this village enough, it blew our minds how gorgeous it was. We needed the chill week by the Adriatic to unwind from all we had already done, and it was perfect. Drove to a few nearby beaches on different days, visited Polignano a Mare, but the highlight of day trips was easily Matera - what an astounding step back in time, just a jaw dropping, mind blowing village. No words can describe. Link in comments. But do yourself a huge favour and visit Monopoli/Puglia, it’s amazing.
Last stop was Milan. Caught the train from Bari after returning our car. A long trip (8hrs) so it wrote off the day, which I hate, but flights had been crazy expensive prior to our departure. Sadly someone decided to steal my suitcase in Bologna - now found but what a saga to get it home 🙈 - which didn’t put us in a good mindset, but we explored Milan nevertheless. Duomo is stunning, esp at night, but the rest of Milan we were quite underwhelmed. I wish we’d perhaps gone to Rome (which we’ve seen maybe four times) for our flight home. Anyway, we won’t die wondering what Milan is like!
So a magnificent - if somewhat busy - trip rich in more memories for our little family. If you want any tips or advice on any of our stops just shout out. All I can say is pack your sense of adventure, an open mind, a teaspoon of patience (some days more than one required😝), your manners, a few Italian phrases, eat lots of gelato and enjoy every second of your holiday! 🇮🇹🙌🥰

text: I have this. Is this all I need for plugging in our phones? Or do I need something in addition? We won’t have hair dryers or curling irons. But I am bringing my good camera (SLR) and will have to plug in my battery pack probably once. I also have mini fans for sleeping. Will I need something for those things? Thanks!

comments.comment_text: Yes, perfect for phones & iPads. Unfortunately, if you plug in a fan that is 110, the 220 surge will destroy it. (I have lived in Sicily for a year & destroyed many American fans plugging them into an adaptor, because I’m forgetful 😂).
took that one and it was great for my phone, kindle and airpods!
I might consider bringing a type L as well.
Some places in Italy have three prongs not two

That will be fine. Most of the hotels we stayed in had jacks for phones that were compatible with our phones. Just needed the places for our cameras, razors, etc. I did take a hair dryer, but just ended up using the ones on the hotels.
That’s a good brand for an adapter. We bought the version that has both USB-A and USB-C outlets.
Can someone recommend a "converter and adapter " in one ? Is that a thing ?
Yes you need that. Some places have USB but not all

One thing that has worked well for us is bring a small power board from home , then you only need one plug converter for the plug board and then all your devices plug into the board with No converter required 😃
